en: The Castellas castle, 12th century A true symbol of the village and former medieval stronghold, the Castellas castle is perched on a promontory in the centre of a green circus. Not far from the latter, a little further south, is the current village. It is probably on the remains of a Roman oppidum that the first stronghold was built in the 9th century. A Carolingian fortress, the "castellas" (in the local language) was built on a rocky outcrop in a loop of the Salendrinque. The castle, as it stands today, has been carefully restored. Built in the 12th century, it was remodelled in the 15th and 17th centuries. This strategic place made it possible to watch over the natural access road to the Cévennes from the plain. At its outlet: the Emerald Valley where the Salendrinque River flows. The choice of this precious stone surely reflects the green of the environment but also symbolizes light and renewal. Originally, gypsum was mined on the site, this mineral which is used to amend the soil and produce plaster... This adds the virtues of fertility and construction to hope. Nice bases to maintain a human presence... Today the castle is private and the interior is not open to the public. The wash-house Another tangible sign that the village is located on a thoroughfare: the wash-house. This equipment is not insignificant: it reflects the will of a society to offer its population the marks of a progress which, not so long ago, was based on hygiene. Recently restored by the municipality, this washhouse is a sign that, even back then, all citizens were given equal consideration, even in the depths of rural areas.
fr: Le château du Castellas, XIIe siècle Véritable symbole du village et ancienne place forte médiévale, le château du Castellas est perché sur un promontoire au centre d'un cirque de verdure. Non loin de ce dernier, un peu plus au Sud, se trouve l'actuel village. C’est vraisemblablement sur les vestiges d’un oppidum romain que fut édifiée la première place forte, au IXe siècle. Forteresse carolingienne, le “castellas” (dans la langue du pays) était édifié sur un piton rocheux, dans une boucle de la Salendrinque. Le château, tel qu’il est aujourd’hui, a bénéficié d’une minutieuse réhabilitation. Edifié au XIIe siècle, il a été remanié aux XVe et XVIIe siècles. Cette place stratégique permettait de surveiller la voie naturelle d’accès aux Cévennes depuis la plaine. À son débouché : le val d’Emeraude où coule la Salendrinque. Le choix de cette pierre précieuse traduit sûrement le vert de l’environnement mais symbolise aussi la lumière et le renouveau. À l’origine, on exploitait du gypse sur le site, ce minéral qui sert à amender les sols et à produire du plâtre… Ce qui permet d’ajouter à l’espérance les vertus de la fertilité et de la construction. Belles bases pour maintenir une présence humaine… Aujourd'hui le château est privé et l'intérieur ne se visite pas. Le lavoir Autre signe tangible montrant que le village est situé sur une voie de passage : le lavoir. Cet équipement n’a rien d’anodin : il traduit la volonté d’une société d’offrir à sa population les marques d’un progrès qui passait, il n’y a pas si longtemps, par l’hygiène. Récemment restauré par la municipalité, ce lavoir signale que, déjà à l’époque, on prenait, en égale considération tous les citoyens, et ce même au plus profond des zones rurales.

hasBeenCreatedBy.schema:legalName: OFFICE DE TOURISME CEVENNES GRAND SUD

hasBeenPublishedBy.schema:logo: https://www.tourismegard.com/Portals/2/Market-place/Le portail des pros du tourisme du Gard_fichiers/logo-Gard-Tourisme.jpg

en:
The Castellas castle, 12th centuryA true symbol of the village and a former medieval stronghold, the Castellas castle is perched on a promontory in the centre of a green cirque. Not far from it, a little further south, is the current village. It is probably on the remains of a Roman oppidum that the first stronghold was built in the 9th century. A Carolingian fortress, the "castellas" (in the local language) was built on a rocky outcrop, in a loop of the Salendrinque river.the castle, as it is today, has benefited from a meticulous rehabilitation. Built in the 12th century, it was reworked in the 15th and 17th centuries.
This strategic place allowed to watch the natural way of access to the Cevennes from the plain. At its outlet: the Emerald Valley where the Salendrinque flows. The choice of this precious stone surely reflects the green of the environment but also symbolizes light and renewal. Originally, gypsum was mined on the site, a mineral used to amend the soil and to produce plaster... This adds to the hope the virtues of fertility and construction. A good basis for maintaining a human presence..
Today the castle is private and the interior is not open to the public.
The washhouseAnother tangible sign showing that the village is situated on a passageway: the washhouse. This equipment is not insignificant: it reflects the will of a society to offer its population the marks of a progress which was, not so long ago, through hygiene. Recently restored by the municipality, this washhouse shows that, already at that time, all citizens were taken into consideration equally, even in the deepest rural areas.

Edifié au XIIe siècle, il a été remanié aux XVe et XVIIe siècles.
Cette place stratégique permettait de surveiller la voie naturelle d’accès aux Cévennes depuis la plaine. À son débouché : le val d’Emeraude où coule la Salendrinque. Le choix de cette pierre précieuse traduit sûrement le vert de l’environnement mais symbolise aussi la lumière et le renouveau. Belles bases pour maintenir une présence humaine…
Aujourd'hui le château est privé et l'intérieur ne se visite pas.
